newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnian central cabinet adopts state budget.
newsitem.headline: Bosnian central cabinet adopts state budget.

text.p: Bosnia's post-war cabinet adopted a state budget on Thursday in a significant boost for reconstruction efforts, a World Bank official said.

The inter-ethnic cabinet, known as the Council of Ministers, ended months of political haggling and adopted the state budget which for the first time outlined the structure of the peacetime government.
"It is a very significant moment in the implementation of the Dayton peace agreement," Rory O'Sullivan, director of the World Bank office in Sarajevo, told Reuters.
Boro Bosic, the Serb co-chairman of the Council of Ministers, said the budget amounted to 136 million German marks ($80 million), state television reported.
Under terms of the peace treaty signed in Dayton, Ohio in 1995, Bosnia is comprised of autonomous Serb and Moslem-Croat entities governed by a small central government.
The two entities control tax revenues and share the burden for covering the budget of the central government ministries, including the ministry of foreign affairs and foreign trade.
Bosic said the council hoped that a part of the budget would be covered by international reconstruction aid.
More than half of the budget was devoted to servicing the country's debt, O'Sullivan said.
The budget still has to be approved by the inter-ethnic parliament but diplomats expected deputies to approve the budget as the same political parties are represented in the council of ministers.
Adoption of the budget law is one of the conditions required for holding an international fund-raising conference for reconstruction which was originally scheduled for March.

Before committing funds to Bosnia, foreign donors want Bosnia to sign an agreement with the International Monetary Fund, which in turn requires the government to pass laws on a single central bank, customs, tariff and foreign debt.
International officials hope to raise $1.4 billion at the conference to help rebuild the economy devastated by the 1992-95 war.
Reaching agreement on a single central bank law is fraught with political difficulties after a war in which Serb separatists fought against Bosnian statehood.
But passing the budget law removed one of the obstacles to the reconstruction conference. O'Sullivan said.
"The size and the role of the state has always been a controversial issue since Dayton.
"There have been different interpretations between the entities on what the state is and that's why it has taken so long...This is an important step." ($ = 1.716 German Marks)
